Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot  as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as fast as possible without involving momentum as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Note: You should perform these exercises as fast as possible but without breaking perfect form and without involving momentum.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly due to the speed that it requires. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: When you are done, do not drop the dumbbells next to you as this is dangerous to your rotator cuff in your shoulders and others working out around you.  \r\n\r\nJust lift your legs from the floor bending at the knees, twist your wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing each other and place the dumbbells on top of your thighs. Focus on moving the forearm.\r\n\r\nAfter a brief pause at the top contraction, inhale and slowly lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: This exercise can be executed also one arm at a time much like the one arm rows are performed.\r\n\r\nAlso, if you like the one arm variety, you can use a low pulley handle instead of a dumbbell for better peak contraction. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width.  For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.\r\n\r\n\t As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso and head forward. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\n\t Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a wider-than-shoulder-width stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance, and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.\r\n\t Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:  This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: \r\n\r\nAs previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.  \r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels if you lack ankle flexibility.  \r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).  \r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a weight belt and attaching weights to it in between the legs.  This variation is referred to as weight belt squats which need to be performed with the legs placed on two well secured, raised but separated platforms that allow the weights to go up and down in the middle. This exercise is an excellent choice for people with lower back problems. p>","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54591m.mp4"},{"name":"Weighted Suitcase Crunch","rating":"9.4","type":"Strength","muscle":"Abdominals","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Medicine Ball","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Begin by lying on your back on the ground. To begin, first place a flat bench or a box behind you.  The flat bench is used to teach you to set your hips back and to hit depth. \r\n\r\nThen, set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\nHold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\nStep away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting your hips back as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you.  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\nVariations: As previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.\r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.\r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).\r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a smith machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the smith machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against smith machine use for squats and if you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/52000/53851m.mp4"},{"name":"Behind Head Chest Stretch","rating":"4.7","type":"Stretching","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":"Shoulders","equipment":"Other","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Expert","guide":"Sit on the floor with your legs comfortably in front of you. It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\nRepeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\nWhen you are done, place the bar back in the rack.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is advised that you use a spotter for this exercise.  If no spotter is available, then be very conservative with the amount of weight used.\r\n\r\nAlso, beware of letting the bar drift too far forward.  You want the bar to be about 1 inch from your neck and nowhere else.\r\n\r\nYou should be in full control of the barbell at all times.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: This exercise can also be performed with the smith machine.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/30000/31801m.mp4"},{"name":"Band Hip Adductions","rating":"8.6","type":"Strength","muscle":"Adductors","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Bands","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Anchor a band around a solid post or other object.\r\n Stand with your left side to the post, and put your right foot through the band, getting it around the ankle.\r\n Stand up straight and hold onto the post if needed. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and hips as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\nRepeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: You can also use a pulley machine, dumbbells or a barbell for this exercise.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/52000/53881m.mp4"},{"name":"Barbell Bench Press-Wide Grip","rating":"8.9","type":"Strength","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":"Shoulders, Triceps","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Load the bar to an appropriate weight for your training. \r\n\r\n Lay on the bench with your feet flat on the ground, driving through your hips. Your back should be arched, and your shoulder blades retracted.\r\n\r\n Take a wide, pronated grip outside of the rings on the bar. Remove the bar from the rack, holding the weight above your chest with your arms extended. This will be your starting position. \r\n\r\n Lower the bar to the sternum by flexing the elbows. Maintain control and do not bounce the bar off of your chest. Your lats should stay tight and elbows slightly drawn in. \r\n\r\n After touching your torso with the bar, extend the elbows to return the bar to the starting position.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/116000/117661m.mp4"},{"name":"Barbell Hack Squat","rating":"8.4","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Forearms, Hamstrings","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Stand up straight while holding a barbell behind you at arms length and your feet at shoulder width. This is a good option for beginners who lack the flexibility to perform the exercise without it.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/52000/53811m.mp4"},{"name":"Barbell Squat To A Bench","rating":"7.3","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings, Lower Back","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Expert","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes.  To begin, first place a flat bench or a box behind you.  The flat bench is used to teach you to set your hips back and to hit depth. \r\n\r\nThen, set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\nHold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\nStep away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees and sitting your hips back as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you.  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs and extend the hips to go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\nVariations: As previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.\r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.\r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).\r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a smith machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the smith machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against smith machine use for squats and if you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/52000/53851m.mp4"},{"name":"Band Pull Apart","rating":"7.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Shoulders","otherMuscles":"Middle Back, Traps","equipment":"Bands","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Begin with your arms extended straight out in front of you, holding the band with both hands.\r\n Initiate the movement by performing a reverse fly motion, moving your hands out laterally to your sides.\r\n Keep your elbows extended as you perform the movement, bringing the band to your chest. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.\r\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight with the elbows pointed out.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight. At the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the receiving position by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. Aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Set up the bands on the sleeves, secured to either band pegs, the rack, or dumbbells so that there is appropriate tension. If dumbbells are used, secure them so that they don't move. Also, ensure that the dumbbells you are using are heavy enough for the bands that you are using. Additional plates can be used to hold the dumbbells down.  If more tension is needed, you can either widen the base on the floor or choke the bands. Squeeze your shoulder blades together and rotate your elbows forward, attempting to bend the bar across your shoulders. Remove the bar from the rack, creating a tight arch in your lower back, and step back into position. Place your feet wider for more emphasis on the back, glutes, adductors, and hamstrings, or closer together for more quad development. Keep your head facing forward.\r\n With your back, shoulders, and core tight, push your knees and butt out and you begin your descent. Sit back with your hips until you are seated on the box. Ideally, your shins should be perpendicular to the ground. Pause when you reach the box, and relax the hip flexors. Never bounce off of a box.\r\n Keeping the weight on your heels and pushing your feet and knees out, drive upward off of the box as you lead the movement with your head. Continue upward, maintaining tightness head to toe. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.\r\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended. \r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. This will be the starting position of the exercise.  Tip: If it is difficult to hold on to the bar with this grip, alternate your grip or use wrist straps. \r\n\r\n\t While holding the bar, start the lift by pushing with your legs while simultaneously getting your torso to the upright position as you breathe out.  In the upright position, stick your chest out and contract the back by bringing the shoulder blades back. When the weights on the bar touch the floor you are back at the starting position and ready to perform another repetition.\r\n\r\n\t Perform the amount of repetitions prescribed in the program.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:  \r\n\r\n\t This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back  straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position. \r\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position. \r\n The second phase is the jerk, which raises the weight overhead. Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible.\r\n Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.\r\n At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athletes effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should be split, with one foot forward, and one foot back. Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you.  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: Be cautious with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.  You may use wrist wraps for this exercise.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: As previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can also use a barbell for this exercise.  Another way to perform these is by using a smith machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the smith machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against smith machine use for squats and if you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54031m.mp4"},{"name":"Cable Deadlifts","rating":"7.7","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Forearms, Glutes, Hamstrings, Lower Back","equipment":"Cable","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Move the cables to the bottom of the towers and select an appropriate weight. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position.\r\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended. \r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/76000/76732m.mp4"},{"name":"Decline Dumbbell Flyes","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight. At the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the receiving position by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. Aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Now while keeping the back flat, bend at the knees and hips so that you can grab the bar with the arms fully extended and a pronated grip that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Point the elbows out to sides. The bar should be close to the shins. \r\nPosition the shoulders over or slightly ahead of the bar. Establish a flat back posture. This will be your starting position.\r\n  Begin to pull the bar by extending the knees. Move your hips forward and raise the shoulders at the same rate while keeping the angle of the back constant; continue to lift the bar straight up while keeping it close to your body.\r\n As the bar passes the knee, extend at the ankles, knees, and hips forcefully, similar to a jumping motion. As you do so, continue to guide the bar with your hands, shrugging your shoulders and using the momentum from your movement to pull the bar as high as possible. The bar should travel close to your body, and you should keep your elbows out. \r\n\r\nAt maximum elevation, your feet should clear the floor and you should start to pull yourself under the bar. The mechanics of this could change slightly, depending on the weight used. You should descend into a squatting position as you pull yourself under the bar.\r\n As the bar hits terminal height, rotate your elbows around and under the bar. Rack the bar across the front of the shoulders while keeping the torso erect and flexing the hips and knees to absorb the weight of the bar.\r\n Stand to full height, holding the bar in the clean position.\r\n Without moving your feet, press the bar overhead as you exhale. Lower your hips with the weight focused on the heels, back  straight, head facing forward, chest up, with your shoulders just in front of the bar. This will be your starting position. \r\n Begin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. Receive the bar in a front squat position, the depth of which is dependent upon the height of the bar at the end of the third pull. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom squat position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up. Continue until you have risen to a standing position. \r\n The second phase is the jerk, which raises the weight overhead. Standing with the weight racked on the front of the shoulders, begin with the dip. With your feet directly under your hips, flex the knees without moving the hips backward. Go down only slightly, and reverse direction as powerfully as possible.\r\n Drive through the heels create as much speed and force as possible, and be sure to move your head out of the way as the bar leaves the shoulders.\r\n At this moment as the feet leave the floor, the feet must be placed into the receiving position as quickly as possible. In the brief moment the feet are not actively driving against the platform, the athletes effort to push the bar up will drive them down. The feet should be split, with one foot forward, and one foot back. Receive the bar with the arms locked out overhead. In this case, you just go up and down from that starting position until you are done with the recommended amount of repetitions.  Then you switch legs and do the same. For walking lunges the leg being left back has to be brought forward after the lunging action has happened in order to continue moving ahead.  This version is reserved for the most advanced athletes.\r\n\r\n\r\nLunges can be performed with dumbbells as described above or with a barbell on the back, though the barbell variety is better suited for the advanced athletes who have mastered the exercise and no longer have balance issues.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/38000/39111m.mp4"},{"name":"Elbow to Knee","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Abdominals","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Body Only","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Lie on the floor, crossing your right leg across your bent left knee. Breathe in as you perform this portion of the movement.\r\n\r\n\t Lift the bar back to the starting position by contracting the triceps and exhaling.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat steps 3-6 until the recommended amount of repetitions is performed.\r\n \r\n\r\nVariations: You can use an e-z bar or dumbbells to perform this movement.  You can also perform it on a flat bench as well.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/38000/38891m.mp4"},{"name":"EZ-Bar Curl","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Biceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"E-Z Curl Bar","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Stand up straight while holding an EZ curl bar at the wide outer handle. The palms of your hands will be facing each other.\r\n\r\nThen, using your thighs to help raise the dumbbells up, lift the dumbbells one at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width.\r\n\r\nOnce at shoulder width, rotate your wrists forward so that the palms of your hands are facing away from you. This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\nThen, as you breathe out, use your chest to push the dumbbells up. At this moment you can place the dumbbells on the floor.\r\n\r\nVariations:\r\n\r\nAnother variation of this exercise is to perform it with the palms of the hands facing each other. \r\n\r\nAlso, you can perform the exercise with the palms facing each other and then twisting the wrist as you lift the dumbbells so that at the top of the movement the palms are facing away from the body. This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\nStep forward with your right leg around 2 feet or so from the foot being left stationary behind and lower your upper body down, while keeping the torso upright and maintaining balance. Make sure that you keep your front shin perpendicular to the ground.\r\n\r\nUsing mainly the heel of your foot, push up and go back to the starting position as you exhale.\r\n\r\nRepeat the movement for the recommended amount of repetitions and then perform with the left leg.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is a movement that requires a great deal of balance so if you suffer from balance problems you may wish to either avoid it or just use your own bodyweight while holding on to a fixed object.  Definitely never perform with a barbell on your back if you suffer from balance issues.\r\n\r\nVariations: There are several ways to perform the exercise.\r\n\r\nOne way is to alternate each leg.  For instance do one repetition with the right, then the left, then the right and so on.\r\n\r\nThe other way is to do what I call a static lunge where your starting position is with one of your feet already forward.  In this case, you just go up and down from that starting position until you are done with the recommended amount of repetitions.  Then you switch legs and do the same.\r\n\r\nA more challenging version is the walking lunges where you walk across the room but in a lunging fashion.  For walking lunges the leg being left back has to be brought forward after the lunging action has happened in order to continue moving ahead.  This version is reserved for the most advanced athletes.\r\n\r\nLunges can be performed with dumbbells as described above or with a barbell on the back, though the barbell variety is better suited for the advanced athletes who have mastered the exercise and no longer have balance issues.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/52000/53981m.mp4"},{"name":"Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension","rating":"8.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Triceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie down with a dumbbell on each hand on top of your thighs. Tip: Make sure to use the same arc of motion used to lower the weights.\r\n\r\n\t Hold for a second at the contracted position and repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariation: You may want to use a palms facing forward version for different stimulation.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/38000/38911m.mp4"},{"name":"Dip Machine","rating":"8.9","type":"Strength","muscle":"Triceps","otherMuscles":"Chest, Shoulders","equipment":"Machine","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Sit securely in a dip machine, select the weight and firmly grasp the handles.\r\n\r\nNow keep your elbows in at your sides in order to place emphasis on the triceps. Additionally, you may perform it with a starting position in which both palms are facing forward. Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section.\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower your torso by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until you slightly touch the bench behind you.  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: Be cautious with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.  You may use wrist wraps for this exercise.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: As previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can also use a barbell for this exercise.  Another way to perform these is by using a smith machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the smith machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against smith machine use for squats and if you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54031m.mp4"},{"name":"Elevated Cable Rows","rating":"8.4","type":"Strength","muscle":"Lats","otherMuscles":"Middle Back, Traps","equipment":"Cable","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Get a platform of some sort (it can be an aerobics or calf raise platform) that is around 4-6 inches in height.\r\n\r\nPlace it on the seat of the cable row machine.\r\n\r\nSit down on the machine and place your feet on the front platform or crossbar provided making sure that your knees are slightly bent and not locked.\r\n\r\nLean over as you keep the natural alignment of your back and grab the V-bar handles.\r\n\r\nWith your arms extended pull back until your torso is at a 90-degree angle from your legs. Exhale as you perform this movement and hold the contraction for a second.\r\n\r\n\t As you inhale, go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: Perform this exercise slowly and deliberately as it takes some getting used to.  Also, do not be hasty and try to use weights on the first time; you'll have enough on your hands learning how to balance yourself.  Also, if balance is an issue I recommend having a spotter next to you and also placing each of your feet under a 100-lb dumbbell for added stability.  As you get more advanced you can hold a dumbbell or a weight plate (held at arms length) on top of your chest.  However, you have to be very careful when adding weight to this exercise, because if you add too much too quickly you could get a hernia.  \r\n\r\nVariations: You can perform this exercise with a low pulley behind you with a rope attached on its end.  In this manner you can go ahead and add resistance easier.  For this variation, you will need to hold on to the sides of the rope throughout the movement.  I like to bring my arms forward to the point that the upper arms are almost parallel to my torso and the lower arms are facing back holding the rope.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54051m.mp4"},{"name":"Elliptical Trainer","rating":"8.9","type":"Cardio","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings","equipment":"Machine","mechanics":"N/A","level":"Intermediate","guide":"To begin, step onto the elliptical and select the desired option from the menu. Elevation can be adjusted to change the intensity of the workout.\r\n The handles can be used to monitor your heart rate to help you stay at an appropriate intensity.\r\n\r\nEllipticals offer convenience, cardiovascular benefits, and have far less impact on joints than ground-based cardio such as running. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor.  Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.\r\n\r\nLift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso. \r\n\r\nStep away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the middle of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The front squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly. To begin, first set a flat bench behind you and set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, bring your arms up under the bar while keeping the elbows high and the upper arm slightly above parallel to the floor.  Rest the bar on top of the deltoids and cross your arms while grasping the bar for total control.\r\n\r\nLift the bar off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\nStep away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances described in the foot positioning section).\r\n\r\nBegin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\nBegin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor mainly with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\nRepeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Receive the bar with your body as low as possible and the arms fully extended overhead.\r\nReturn to a standing position with the weight overhead, and then return the weight to the floor under control.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/76000/77632m.mp4"},{"name":"Hanging Pike","rating":"9.1","type":"Strength","muscle":"Abdominals","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Body Only","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Expert","guide":"Hang from a chin-up bar with your legs and feet together using an overhand grip (palms facing away from you) that is slightly wider than shoulder width. Tip: It is important to tighten the glutes and hamstrings as this will cause the hip flexors to be inactivated in a process called reciprocal inhibition, which basically means that opposite muscles to the contracted ones will relax.\r\n\t As you inhale, slowly go back in a controlled manner to the starting position.\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: The exercise can be done using a dedicated abdominal bench apparatus, having a workout partner exert pulling pressure on your calves (while you maintain your feet on the ground) or wrapping your legs over barbell and pulling back.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40411m.mp4"},{"name":"Incline Inner Biceps Curl","rating":"7.9","type":"Strength","muscle":"Biceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lie back on an incline bench.\r\n\r\n\t The dumbbells should be at arm's length hanging at your sides and your palms should be facing out. Tip: It is important to tighten the glutes and hamstrings as this will cause the hip flexors to be inactivated in a process called reciprocal inhibition, which basically means that opposite muscles to the contracted ones will relax.\r\n\t As you inhale, slowly go back in a controlled manner to the starting position.\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: The exercise can be done using a dedicated abdominal bench apparatus, having a workout partner exert pulling pressure on your calves (while you maintain your feet on the ground) or wrapping your legs over barbell and pulling back.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40411m.mp4"},{"name":"JM Press With Bands","rating":null,"type":"Strength","muscle":"Triceps","otherMuscles":"Chest, Shoulders","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Load the bar to an appropriate weight for your training. You do not want that platform falling on you fully loaded.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: Always check to make sure that when you re-rack the weight the platform is securely locked.\r\n\r\nVariations: All foot stance variations described in the foot stance section.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40571m.mp4"},{"name":"Lying Leg Curls","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Hamstrings","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Machine","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Adjust the machine lever to fit your height and lie face down on the leg curl machine with the pad of the lever on the back of your legs (just a few inches under the calves). Continue until your upper arms are parallel to the floor.\r\n\r\n Pause briefly, and then return to the starting position.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/116000/117941m.mp4"},{"name":"Narrow Stance Squats","rating":"8.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings, Lower Back","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes.  To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\n\t Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Feet should be around 3-6 inches apart.  Keep your head up at all times (looking down will get you off balance) and maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\n\t Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:  This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: \r\n\r\n\r\nAs previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.  \r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.  \r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide-stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).  \r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a weight belt and attaching weights to it in between the legs.  This variation is referred to as weight-belt squats which need to be performed with the legs placed on two well secured, raised, but separated platforms, that allow the weights to go up and down in the middle. This exercise is an excellent choice for people with lower back problems.  The issue however is finding the platforms that meet the criteria.  The only way I have been able to perform this is when I have two benches placed opposite to each other with spotting platforms that are facing each other.  If you move the benches close enough then you get can execute the weight-belt squats by using the spotting platform. \r\n\r\nFinally, you can also perform squats in a Smith Machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the Smith Machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against Smith Machine use for squats. If you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54271m.mp4"},{"name":"Medicine Ball Chest Pass","rating":"5.6","type":"Plyometrics","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":"Shoulders, Triceps","equipment":"Medicine Ball","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"You will need a partner for this exercise. This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your neck.\r\n\r\n\t After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles. To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\n\t Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a less-than-shoulder-width narrow stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Feet should be around 3-6 inches apart.  Keep your head up at all times (looking down will get you off balance) and maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\n\t Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:  This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: \r\n\r\n\r\nAs previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.  \r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels to improve balance.  \r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide-stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).  \r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a weight belt and attaching weights to it in between the legs.  This variation is referred to as weight-belt squats which need to be performed with the legs placed on two well secured, raised, but separated platforms, that allow the weights to go up and down in the middle. This exercise is an excellent choice for people with lower back problems.  The issue however is finding the platforms that meet the criteria.  The only way I have been able to perform this is when I have two benches placed opposite to each other with spotting platforms that are facing each other.  If you move the benches close enough then you get can execute the weight-belt squats by using the spotting platform. \r\n\r\nFinally, you can also perform squats in a Smith Machine though I do not recommend this.  The reason for not performing regular squats on the Smith Machine is that since the machine allows you to execute the exercise while leaning versus the bar, hip flexor involvement is minimized taking the hamstring out of the exercise.  While this does take pressure off the lower back, hamstring involvement is a requirement to stabilize the knee-cap.  So, as a result, what is created is a situation where destructive forces place a huge stress on the ACL (anterior cruciate ligament; a primary ligament in the knee capsule whose job is to provide knee stability) by pushing the knee-cap forward.  For this reason, I highly recommend against Smith Machine use for squats. If you still insist on doing so, make sure it is a sporadic use rather than frequent, and also be sure to control the amount of weight used.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54271m.mp4"},{"name":"Oblique Crunches - On The Floor","rating":"7.7","type":"Strength","muscle":"Abdominals","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Body Only","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Start out by lying on your right side with your legs lying on top of each other. By using dumbbells you will be able to isolate your chest and add some variety to your workouts.\r\n\r\nCaution: When you are done, do not drop the barbell or dumbbell next to you as this is dangerous to your rotator cuff in your shoulders and others working out around you.  A better way to do this is to use both of your hands to grab the barbell or dumbbell and place it to your side.  Simply move the barbell or dumbbell away from the arm you are exercising before dropping the weights.  This will ensure optimal safety and prevent any injuries.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/41311m.mp4"},{"name":"On-Your-Back Quad Stretch","rating":"3.3","type":"Stretching","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Other","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Lie on a flat bench or step, and hang one leg and arm over the side.\r\n Bend the knee and hold the top of the foot. Note on grips: For a wide grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance wider than your shoulder width.  For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.\r\n\r\n\t As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso back around 30 degrees or so while creating a curvature on your lower back and sticking your chest out.  This is your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Pull your torso up until the bar touches your upper chest by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back. The upper torso should remain stationary as it moves through space and only the arms should move.  The forearms should do no other work other than hold the bar.\r\n\r\n\t After a second on the contracted position, start to inhale and slowly lower your torso back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: \r\n\r\n\t If you are new at this exercise and do not have the strength to perform it, use a chin assist machine if available.  These machines use weight to help you push your bodyweight.\r\n\r\n\t Otherwise, a spotter holding your legs can help.\r\n\r\n\t On the other hand, more advanced lifters can add weight to the exercise by using a weight belt that allows the addition of weighted plates.\r\n\r\n\t The behind the neck variation is not recommended as it can be hard on the rotator cuff due to the hyperextension created by bringing the bar behind the neck.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40861m.mp4"},{"name":"Plie Dumbbell Squat","rating":"8.4","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Abdominals, Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings","equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Hold a dumbbell at the base with both hands and stand straight up. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart outside knees with elbows fully extended.\r\n\r\nPlace the bar about 1 inch in front of your shins and over the balls of your feet.\r\n\r\nYour back should be flat or slightly arched, your chest held up and out and your shoulder blades should be retracted.\r\n\r\nKeep your head in a neutral position (in line with vertebral column and not tilted or rotated) with your eyes focused straight ahead. Inhale during this phase.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 2: First Pull Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nLift the bar from the floor by forcefully extending the hips and the knees as you exhale.  Tip: The upper torso should maintain the same angle.  Do not bend at the waist yet and do not let the hips rise before the shoulders (this would have the effect of pushing the glutes in the air and stretching the hamstrings.\r\n\r\nKeep elbows fully extended with the head in a neutral position and the shoulders over the bar.\r\n\r\nAs the bar raises keep it as close to the shins as possible.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 3: Transition or Scoop Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nAs the bar passes the knees, thrust your hips forward and slightly bend the knees to avoid locking them. Tip: At this point your thighs should be against the bar.\r\n\r\nKeep the back flat or slightly arched, elbows fully extended and your head neutral. Tip: You will hold your breath until the next phase.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 4: Second Pull Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nInhale and then forcefully and quickly extend your hips and knees and stand on your toes.\r\n\r\nKeep the bar as close to your body as possible.  Tip: Your back should be flat with the elbows pointed out to the sides and your head in a neutral position.  Also, keep your shoulders over the bar and arms straight as long as possible.\r\n\r\nWhen your lower body joints are fully extended, shrug the shoulders upward rapidly without letting the elbows flex yet. Exhale during this portion of the movement.\r\n\r\nAs the shoulders reach their highest elevation flex your elbows to begin pulling your body under the bar.\r\n\r\nContinue to pull the arms as high and as long as possible. Tip: Due to the explosive nature of this phase, your torso will be erect or with an arched back, your head will be tilted back slightly and your feet may lose contact with the floor.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 5: Catch Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter the lower body has fully extended and the bar reaches near maximal height, pull your body under the bar and rotate the arms around and under the bar.\r\n\r\nSimultaneously, flex the hips and knees into a quarter squat position.\r\n\r\nOnce the arms are under the bar, inhale and then lift your elbows to position the upper arms parallel to the floor. Rack the bar across the front of your collar bones and front shoulder muscles.\r\n\r\nCatch the bar with an erect and tight torso, a neutral head position and flat feet. Exhale during this movement.\r\n\r\nStand up by extending the hips and knees to a fully erect position.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 6: Downward Movement Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nLower the bar by gradually reducing the muscular tension of the arms to allow a controlled descent of the bar to the thighs. Inhale during this movement.\r\n\r\nSimultaneously flex the hips and knees to cushion the impact of the bar on the thighs.\r\n\r\nSquat down with the elbows fully extended until the bar touches the floor.\r\n\r\nStart over at Phase 1 and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/98000/99822m.mp4"},{"name":"Pushups","rating":"9.2","type":"Strength","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":"Shoulders, Triceps","equipment":"Body Only","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart while holding your torso up at arms length.\r\n\r\nNext, lower yourself downward until your chest almost touches the floor as you inhale.\r\n\r\nNow breathe out and press your upper body back up to the starting position while squeezing your chest.\r\n\r\nAfter a brief pause at the top contracted position, you can begin to lower yourself downward again for as many repetitions as needed.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations:\r\n\r\nIf you are new at this exercise and do not have the strength to perform it, you can either bend your legs at the knees to take off resistance or perform the exercise against the wall instead of the floor.\r\n\r\nFor the most advanced lifters, you can place your feet at a high surface such as a bench in order to increase the resistance and to target the upper chest more.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40811m.mp4"},{"name":"Push-Ups With Feet Elevated","rating":"8.5","type":"Strength","muscle":"Chest","otherMuscles":"Shoulders, Triceps","equipment":"Body Only","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"Lie on the floor face down and place your hands about 36 inches apart from each other holding your torso up at arms length.\r\n\r\n\t Place your toes on top of a flat bench. Your hands should be slightly wider than shoulder width apart outside knees with elbows fully extended.\r\n\r\nPlace the bar about 1 inch in front of your shins and over the balls of your feet.\r\n\r\nYour back should be flat or slightly arched, your chest held up and out and your shoulder blades should be retracted.\r\n\r\nKeep your head in a neutral position (in line with vertebral column and not tilted or rotated) with your eyes focused straight ahead. Inhale during this phase.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 2: First Pull Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nLift the bar from the floor by forcefully extending the hips and the knees as you exhale.  Tip: The upper torso should maintain the same angle.  Do not bend at the waist yet and do not let the hips rise before the shoulders (this would have the effect of pushing the glutes in the air and stretching the hamstrings.\r\n\r\nKeep elbows fully extended with the head in a neutral position and the shoulders over the bar.\r\n\r\nAs the bar raises keep it as close to the shins as possible.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 3: Transition or Scoop Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nAs the bar passes the knees, thrust your hips forward and slightly bend the knees to avoid locking them. Tip: At this point your thighs should be against the bar.\r\n\r\nKeep the back flat or slightly arched, elbows fully extended and your head neutral. Tip: You will hold your breath until the next phase.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 4: Second Pull Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nInhale and then forcefully and quickly extend your hips and knees and stand on your toes.\r\n\r\nKeep the bar as close to your body as possible.  Tip: Your back should be flat with the elbows pointed out to the sides and your head in a neutral position.  Also, keep your shoulders over the bar and arms straight as long as possible.\r\n\r\nWhen your lower body joints are fully extended, shrug the shoulders upward rapidly without letting the elbows flex yet. Exhale during this portion of the movement.\r\n\r\nAs the shoulders reach their highest elevation flex your elbows to begin pulling your body under the bar.\r\n\r\nContinue to pull the arms as high and as long as possible. Tip: Due to the explosive nature of this phase, your torso will be erect or with an arched back, your head will be tilted back slightly and your feet may lose contact with the floor.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 5: Catch Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter the lower body has fully extended and the bar reaches near maximal height, pull your body under the bar and rotate the arms around and under the bar.\r\n\r\nSimultaneously, flex the hips and knees into a quarter squat position.\r\n\r\nOnce the arms are under the bar, inhale and then lift your elbows to position the upper arms parallel to the floor. Rack the bar across the front of your collar bones and front shoulder muscles.\r\n\r\nCatch the bar with an erect and tight torso, a neutral head position and flat feet. Exhale during this movement.\r\n\r\nStand up by extending the hips and knees to a fully erect position.\r\n\r\n\r\nPhase 6: Downward Movement Phase\r\n\r\n\r\nLower the bar by gradually reducing the muscular tension of the arms to allow a controlled descent of the bar to the thighs. Inhale during this movement.\r\n\r\nSimultaneously flex the hips and knees to cushion the impact of the bar on the thighs.\r\n\r\nSquat down with the elbows fully extended until the bar touches the floor.\r\n\r\nStart over at Phase 1 and repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/98000/99822m.mp4"},{"name":"Power Partials","rating":"9.2","type":"Strength","muscle":"Shoulders","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Stand up with your torso upright and a dumbbell on each hand being held at arms length.  The elbows should be close to the torso.\r\n\r\n\t The palms of the hands should be facing your torso.  Your feet should be about shoulder width apart. This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Keeping your arms straight and the torso stationary, lift the weights out to your sides until they are about shoulder level height while exhaling.\r\n\r\n\t Feel the contraction for a second and begin to lower the weights back down to the starting position while inhaling. Tip: Keep the palms facing down with the little finger slightly higher while lifting and lowering the weights as it will concentrate the stress on your shoulders mainly.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: There are many possible variations for this movement.  For instance, you can perform the exercise sitting down on a bench with or without back support and you can also perform it by alternating arms; first lift the right arm for one repetition, then the left, then the right, etc.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40921m.mp4"},{"name":"Power Stairs","rating":"9.2","type":"Strongman","muscle":"Hamstrings","otherMuscles":"Adductors, Calves, Glutes, Lower Back, Quadriceps, Shoulders, Traps","equipment":"Other","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"In the power stairs, implements are moved up a staircase. Avoid excessive forward lean, rounding your lumbar or thoracic spine, and keep the kettlebell in place throughout the exercise.\r\n\r\n After a brief pause, return to the starting position by extending through the hips and knees. This will be your starting position. \r\nBegin the first pull by driving through the heels, extending your knees. Your back angle should stay the same, and your arms should remain straight. Move the weight with control as you continue to above the knees.\r\n Next comes the second pull, the main source of acceleration for the clean. As the bar approaches the mid-thigh position, begin extending through the hips. In a jumping motion, accelerate by extending the hips, knees, and ankles, using speed to move the bar upward. There should be no need to actively pull through the arms to accelerate the weight; at the end of the second pull, the body should be fully extended, leaning slightly back, with the arms still extended.\r\n As full extension is achieved, transition into the third pull by aggressively shrugging and flexing the arms with the elbows up and out. At peak extension, aggressively pull yourself down, rotating your elbows under the bar as you do so. \r\nReceive the bar with the feet split, aggressively moving one foot forward and one foot back. The bar should be racked onto the protracted shoulders, lightly touching the throat with the hands relaxed. Continue to descend to the bottom position, which will help in the recovery.  \r\nImmediately recover by driving through the heels, keeping the torso upright and elbows up.
