Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\n\t Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement. Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as fast as possible without involving momentum as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position. Note: You should perform these exercises as fast as possible but without breaking perfect form and without involving momentum.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly due to the speed that it requires. Exhale as you perform this movement\r\n\r\n\t Start bringing your torso up straight again by extending your hips and waist until you are back at the starting position.  Inhale as you perform this movement.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise that is recommended for people with lower back problems.  Also, it needs to be treated with the utmost respect paying special attention not to round the back forward as you move the torso down; the back should always be straight. Like many other arm exercises, only the forearm moves.\r\n\r\n\t After a second contraction at the top, slowly lower the dumbbell back to the starting position as you inhale.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\t Switch arms and repeat the exercise.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations:\r\n  \r\n\r\n\t This exercise can be executed also with two arms at a time.\r\n\r\n\t Also, if you like the one arm variety, you can use a low pulley handle instead of a dumbbell for better peak contraction.  In this case, the palms should be facing up (supinated grip) as opposed to the torso (neutral grip). Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the bar on the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck).\r\n\r\n\t  Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t  Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out. Tip: Make sure that as opposed to a regular bench press, you keep the elbows close to the torso at all times in order to maximize triceps involvement.\r\n\r\n\t After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your triceps muscles.  Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\t When you are done, lock the bar back in the rack.\r\n  \r\n\r\nCaution: If you are new at this exercise, it is advised that you use a spotter as this exercise can be a bit challenging.  If no spotter is available, then be conservative with the amount of weight used.  \r\n\r\nVariations: This exercise can also be performed with a barbell or e-z bar using the inner handle as well as dumbbells in which case the palms of the hands will be facing each other.  \r\n\r\nSame as the Barbell Close-Grip Bench Press but with a Smith Machine.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54461m.mp4"},{"name":"Seated Calf Raise","rating":"8.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Calves","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Machine","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Sit on the machine and place your toes on the lower portion of the platform provided with the heels extending off. Attempt to keep the ends of the chains away from the plates so you don't hit them when you lower the weight. \r\nBegin with a bar loaded on the ground. Approach the bar so that the bar intersects the middle of the feet. The feet should be set very wide, near the collars. Bend at the hips to grip the bar. The arms should be directly below the shoulders, inside the legs, and you can use a pronated grip, a mixed grip, or hook grip. Relax the shoulders, which in effect lengthens your arms.\r\n Take a breath, and then lower your hips, looking forward with your head with your chest up. Drive through the floor, spreading your feet apart, with your weight on the back half of your feet. Extend through the hips and knees.\r\n As the bar passes through the knees, lean back and drive the hips into the bar, pulling your shoulder blades together.\r\n Return the weight to the ground by bending at the hips and controlling the weight on the way down.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/76000/77492m.mp4"},{"name":"Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning","rating":"8.1","type":"Strength","muscle":"Lower Back","otherMuscles":"Glutes, Hamstrings","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Beginner","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes. If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot  as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This is not an exercise to be taken lightly. Return to the neutral position in a slow and controlled manner.\r\n\r\nRepeat to failure.\r\n\r\nThen, reposition and repeat the same series of movements on the opposite side.\r\n\r\nTip: You will twist your entire body with this exercise, but focus on getting maximal torso rotation and a strong clinch at the end of the movement. A smith machine can be used for calf raises as well.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/41821m.mp4"},{"name":"Standing Palms-Up Barbell Behind The Back Wrist Curl","rating":"9.3","type":"Strength","muscle":"Forearms","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Start by standing straight and holding a barbell behind your glutes at arm's length while using a pronated grip (palms will be facing back away from the glutes) and having your hands shoulder width apart from each other.\r\n\r\n\t You should be looking straight forward while your feet are shoulder width apart from each other. This is the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t While exhaling, slowly elevate the barbell up by curling your wrist in a semi-circular motion towards the ceiling.  Note: Your wrist should be the only body part moving for this exercise.\r\n\r\n\t Hold the contraction for a second and lower the barbell back down to the starting position while inhaling.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\t When finished, lower the barbell down to the squat rack or the floor by bending the knees. The palms of your hand will be facing each other.\r\n\r\n\t By using your thighs to help you get the dumbbells up, clean the dumbbells one arm at a time so that you can hold them in front of you at shoulder width.  Note: when holding the dumbbells in front of you, make sure your arms are wider than shoulder width apart from each other using a pronated (palms forward) grip. Allow your elbows to point out. This is your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Keeping the upper arms stationary, slowly move the dumbbells in and down in a semi circular motion until they touch the upper chest while inhaling.  Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times and do not move the upper arms nor rest the dumbbells on the chest.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe out, move the dumbbells up using your triceps and the same semi-circular motion but in reverse. Attempt to keep the dumbbells together as they move up. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down again slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: When you are done, do not drop the dumbbells next to you as this is dangerous to your rotator cuff in your shoulders and others working out around you.  \r\n\r\nJust lift your legs from the floor bending at the knees, twist your wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing each other and place the dumbbells on top of your thighs.  When both dumbbells are touching your thighs simultaneously push your upper torso up (while pressing the dumbbells on your thighs) and also perform a slight kick forward with your legs (keeping the dumbbells on top of the thighs).  By doing this combined movement, momentum will help you get back to a sitting position with both dumbbells still on top of your thighs. Keep full control of the dumbbells at all times and do not move the upper arms nor rest the dumbbells on the chest.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe out, move the dumbbells up using your triceps and the same semi-circular motion but in reverse. Attempt to keep the dumbbells together as they move up. Lock your arms in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down again slowly again. Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions of your training program.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: When you are done, do not drop the dumbbells next to you as this is dangerous to your rotator cuff in your shoulders and others working out around you.  \r\n\r\nJust lift your legs from the floor bending at the knees, twist your wrists so that the palms of your hands are facing each other and place the dumbbells on top of your thighs.  When both dumbbells are touching your thighs simultaneously push your upper torso up (while pressing the dumbbells on your thighs) and also perform a slight kick forward with your legs (keeping the dumbbells on top of the thighs).  By doing this combined movement, momentum will help you get back to a sitting position with both dumbbells still on top of your thighs.  At this moment you can place the dumbbells on the floor.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54531m.mp4"},{"name":"Triceps Overhead Extension with Rope","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Triceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Cable","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Attach a rope to a low pulley. After selecting an appropriate weight, grasp the rope with both hands and face away from the cable.\r\n Position your hands behind your head with your elbows point straight up. Your elbows should start out flexed, and you can stagger your stance and lean gently away from the machine to create greater stability. This will be your starting position.\r\n To perform the movement, extend through the elbow while keeping the upper arm in position, raising your hands above your head.\r\n Squeeze your triceps at the top of the movement, and slowly lower the weight back to the start position.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/94000/94782m.mp4"},{"name":"Triceps Pushdown - V-Bar Attachment","rating":"9.0","type":"Strength","muscle":"Triceps","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Cable","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Beginner","guide":"Attach a V-Bar to a high pulley and grab with an overhand grip (palms facing down) at shoulder width.\r\n\r\n\t Standing upright with the torso straight and a very small inclination forward, bring the upper arms close to your body and perpendicular to the floor.  The forearms should be pointing up towards the pulley as they hold the bar. The thumbs should be higher than the small finger.  This is your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Using the triceps, bring the bar down until it touches the front of your thighs and the arms are fully extended perpendicular to the floor.  The upper arms should always remain stationary next to your torso and only the forearms should move.  Exhale as you perform this movement.\r\n\r\n\t After a second hold at the contracted position, bring the V-Bar slowly up to the starting point.  Breathe in as you perform this step.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: There are many variations to this movement. Also, make sure that there is nothing behind you; as in the case that you lose your balance and fall, that way nothing will hit you on the head causing an injury.\r\n\r\nVariations: If you are new to this exercise, you can start by using two arms (so you'll need the two beams of the squat rack in front of you to hold yourself). For a medium grip, your hands need to be spaced out at a distance equal to your shoulder width and for a close grip at a distance smaller than your shoulder width.\r\n\r\n\t As you have both arms extended in front of you holding the bar at the chosen grip width, bring your torso and head forward. Think of an imaginary line from the center of the bar down to the back of your neck. This is your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe out, bring the bar down until it touches the back of your neck by drawing the shoulders and the upper arms down and back.  Tip: Concentrate on squeezing the back muscles once you reach the full contracted position.  The upper torso should remain stationary and only the arms should move.  The forearms should do no other work except for holding the bar; therefore do not try to pull down the bar using the forearms.\r\n\r\n\t After a second on the contracted position squeezing your shoulder blades together, slowly raise the bar back to the starting position when your arms are fully extended and the lats are fully stretched.  Inhale during this portion of the movement.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat this motion for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: Performing this exercise can be hard on the rotator cuffs and if not properly executed can cause an injury to occur.  Also, if you already have rotator cuff issues, I advise you to stick to the front pull-down version.\r\n\r\nVariations: You can also performing this exercise by bring the bar down and touching your chest.  This variation is safer and not as hard on the rotator cuffs.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/41401m.mp4"},{"name":"Wide Stance Barbell Squat","rating":"8.5","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings, Lower Back","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes.  To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, step under the bar and place the back of your shoulders (slightly below the neck) across it.\r\n\r\n\t Hold on to the bar using both arms at each side and lift it off the rack by first pushing with your legs and at the same time straightening your torso.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a wider-than-shoulder-width stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance, and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.\r\n\t Begin to slowly lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the heel of your foot as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:  This is not an exercise to be taken lightly.  If you have back issues, substitute it with the dumbbell squat variation or a leg press instead.  If you have a healthy back, ensure perfect form and never slouch the back forward as this can cause back injury. Be cautious as well with the weight used; in case of doubt, use less weight rather than more.  The squat is a very safe exercise but only if performed properly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nVariations: \r\n\r\nAs previously mentioned, there are various stances that can be used depending on what you want to emphasize.  \r\n\r\nYou can also place a small block under the heels if you lack ankle flexibility.  \r\n\r\nDumbbells can be used as well for resistance by holding them to your sides.  The use of wrist wraps is a necessity due to the amount of weights used.  I find this an excellent variation when my lower back begins to act up after many weeks of regular barbell squats.  (Note: For wide stance dumbbell squats you will have to hold the dumbbells in between your legs as opposed to both sides in order to be able to distance your legs sufficiently).  \r\n\r\nAnother way to perform these is by using a weight belt and attaching weights to it in between the legs.  This variation is referred to as weight belt squats which need to be performed with the legs placed on two well secured, raised but separated platforms that allow the weights to go up and down in the middle. This exercise is an excellent choice for people with lower back problems. p>","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54591m.mp4"},{"name":"Weighted Suitcase Crunch","rating":"9.4","type":"Strength","muscle":"Abdominals","otherMuscles":null,"equipment":"Medicine Ball","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Begin by lying on your back on the ground. Using a wide, pronated (palms forward) grip that is around 3 inches away from shoulder width (for each hand), lift the bar from the rack and hold it straight over you with your arms locked.  The bar will be perpendicular to the torso and the floor.  This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe in, come down slowly until you feel the bar on your middle chest.\r\n\r\n\t After a second pause, bring the bar back to the starting position as you breathe out and push the bar using your chest muscles.  Lock your arms and squeeze your chest in the contracted position, hold for a second and then start coming down slowly again.  Tip: It should take at least twice as long to go down than to come up.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat the movement for the prescribed amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution:\r\n \r\n\r\n\t If you are new at this exercise, it is advised that you use a spotter.  If no spotter is available, then be conservative with the amount of weight used.\r\n\r\n\t Also, beware of letting the bar drift too far forward.  You want the bar to fall on your middle chest and nowhere else.\r\n\r\n\t Don't bounce the weight off your chest. With your head looking forward and back arched, lift the yoke by driving through the heels.\r\n Begin walking as quickly as possible using short, quick steps. You may hold the side posts of the yoke to help steady it and hold it in position. Continue for the given distance as fast as possible, usually 75-100 feet.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/76000/77432m.mp4"},{"name":"Zottman Preacher Curl","rating":"7.5","type":"Strength","muscle":"Biceps","otherMuscles":"Forearms","equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Grab a dumbbell in each hand and place your upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench.  The dumbbells should be held at shoulder height and the elbows should be flexed.  Hold the dumbbells with the palms of your hands facing down.  This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t As you breathe in, slowly lower the dumbbells keeping the palms down until your upper arm is extended and your biceps are fully stretched.\r\n\r\n\t Now rotate your wrists once you are at the bottom of the movement so that the palms of the hands are facing up.\r\n\r\n\t As you exhale, use your biceps to curl the weights up until they are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder height.  Again, remember that to ensure full contraction you need to bring that small finger higher than the thumb.\r\n\r\n\t Squeeze the biceps hard for a second at the contracted position and rotate your wrists so that the palms are facing down again.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40601m.mp4"},{"name":"Zercher Squats","rating":"7.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Expert","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes.  To begin, first set the bar on a rack that best matches your height.  The correct height should be anywhere above the waist but below the chest. Once the correct height is chosen and the bar is loaded, lock your hands together and place the bar on top of your arms in between the forearm and upper arm.\r\n\r\n\t Lift the bar up so that it is resting on top of your forearms.  If you are holding the bar properly, it should look as if you have your arms crossed but with a bar running across them.\r\n\r\n\t Step away from the rack and position your legs using a shoulder width medium stance with the toes slightly pointed out.  Keep your head up at all times as looking down will get you off balance and also maintain a straight back.  This will be your starting position.  (Note: For the purposes of this discussion we will use the medium stance described above which targets overall development; however you can choose any of the three stances discussed in the foot stances section).\r\n\r\n\t Begin to lower the bar by bending the knees as you maintain a straight posture with the head up.  Continue down until the angle between the upper leg and the calves becomes slightly less than 90-degrees (which is the point in which the upper legs are below parallel to the floor).  Inhale as you perform this portion of the movement.  Tip: If you performed the exercise correctly, the front of the knees should make an imaginary straight line with the toes that is perpendicular to the front.  If your knees are past that imaginary line (if they are past your toes) then you are placing undue stress on the knee and the exercise has been performed incorrectly.\r\n\r\n\t Begin to raise the bar as you exhale by pushing the floor with the ball of your foot mainly as you straighten the legs again and go back to the starting position.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.\r\n\r\n\r\nCaution: This exercise is not to be taken lightly as you are applying a lot of pressure to your arms when lifting the barbell.  It is always a good idea to have a spotter as they can help you keep proper form.  Also, make sure that your back is kept straight as bending it can cause an injury.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/54000/54601m.mp4"},{"name":"Zottman Preacher Curl","rating":"7.5","type":"Strength","muscle":"Biceps","otherMuscles":"Forearms","equipment":"Dumbbell","mechanics":"Isolation","level":"Intermediate","guide":"Grab a dumbbell in each hand and place your upper arms on top of the preacher bench or the incline bench. The elbows should be close to the torso.\r\n\r\n\t Make sure the palms of the hands are facing each other.  This will be your starting position.\r\n\r\n\t While holding the upper arm stationary, curl the weights while contracting the biceps as you breathe out.  Only the forearms should move.  Your wrist should rotate so that you have a supinated (palms up) grip.  Continue the movement until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level.\r\n\r\n\t Hold the contracted position for a second as you squeeze the biceps.\r\n\r\n\t Now during the contracted position, rotate your wrist until you now have a pronated (palms facing down) grip with the thumb at a higher position than the pinky.\r\n\r\n\t Slowly begin to bring the dumbbells back down using the pronated grip.\r\n\r\n\t As the dumbbells close your thighs, start rotating the wrist so that you go back to a neutral (palms facing your body) grip.\r\n\r\n\t Repeat for the recommended amount of repetitions.","url":"http://videocdn.bodybuilding.com/video/mp4/40000/40601m.mp4"},{"name":"Zercher Squats","rating":"7.8","type":"Strength","muscle":"Quadriceps","otherMuscles":"Calves, Glutes, Hamstrings","equipment":"Barbell","mechanics":"Compound","level":"Expert","guide":"This exercise is best performed inside a squat rack for safety purposes.
